DocConceptRoot.Name: Superstructure
DocConceptRoot.Documentation: The superstructure of a bridge refers to those elements than span horizontally to carry loads onto substructures.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Name
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Name of the superstructure for organizational purposes.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Alignments
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Alignment objects used longitudinally (e.g. for girders) or laterally (e.g. for floor beams).

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Trusses
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Truss lines.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Girders
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Girder lines.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Cross Frames
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Cross frames between girder lines.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Floor Beams
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Floor beams between girder lines.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Stringers
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Stringers between floor beams.

DocConceptRoot.Name: Girder
DocConceptRoot.Documentation: Bridge girders refer to horizontal support beams that span along the alignment of a bridge. For steel girders, this refers to each girder line, decomposed into beam segments. For concrete box girders, this refers to the overall box girder, typically connected to the bridge deck via a keyed construction joint with adjoining reinforcing.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Name
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Name of the girder line for referencing purposes as would be found on construction plans.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Alignment
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Reference to the alignment object used to position the girder line.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Axis
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Axis curve defined as a sub-span with offsets relative to the alignment curve.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Type
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Template defining general construction that may be used across projects.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Material
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Common material that applies to all segments of the girder.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Segments
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Segmented girders may be decomposed into segments for each continuous section.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Components
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Built-up girders may be decomposed into plates (or members) for web, flanges, cover plates, longitudinal stiffeners, and vertical stiffeners.

DocConceptRoot.Name: Girder Segment
DocConceptRoot.Documentation: Girder segments refer to discrete sections along a girder line. They may be modelled as one object that encapsulates the overall cross section (e.g. I-Shape steel, arbitrary precast profile), or as separate objects (e.g. steel flange plates, steel web plate). Each segment may have a constant cross section, a tapered cross section (linearly interpolated from start to end), a variable cross section (linearly interpolated at multiple points between start and end), or free-form geometry. The connection between beams is represented using IfcRelConnectsWithRealizingElements, where the RealizingElements refers to IfcPlate elements for fastening plates on each side, IfcFastener for bolts, and IfcPlate for any flange transition plates. The reason for using this connection relationship specifically (as opposed to just placing the elements) is to be able to derive an IfcStructuralAnalysisModel that captures the beam connectivity.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Name
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Name of the girder segment for referencing purposes as would be found on construction plans.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Material
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Material of the girder segment.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Solid Geometry
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Geometry of the girder segment defined as a cross section that may be constant or variable (linearly or parabolic), swept along the alignment at starting and ending positions.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Connection Head
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Relationship connecting head of girder segment with abutment or another girder segment, where realizing element refers to splice plates.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Connection Tail
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Relationship connecting tail of girder segment with another girder segment or abutment, where realizing element refers to splice plates.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Connection Support
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Relationship connecting girder segment to substructure, where realizing element refers to bearing if present.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Reinforcing
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: For concrete girders, reinforcing embedded.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Tendons
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: For concrete girders, tendons embedded.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Stiffeners
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: For steel girders, web stiffeners placed at intervals along inside face(s) of web.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Shear Studs
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: For steel girders, shear studs placed at intervals along top flange.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Camber
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: For steel girders, camber ordinates for fabrication.

DocConceptRoot.Name: Cross Frame
DocConceptRoot.Documentation: Bridge cross frames connect two girders laterally. Cross-framing between girders may be described using templates of member configurations. Such cross framing is captured within components, using standard shapes (e.g. AISC in U.S.) where applicable. For curved alignments where girders are placed at different elevations, members must be placed relative to the girders at each side, for which positioning is defined relative to alignment curves. Such cross-framing is then instantiated as object occurrences according to repetition intervals, where each occurrence has unique connectivity relationships with corresponding girder segments.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Name
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Name of cross frame occurrence as would be identified on construction plans.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Plates
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Plates used within cross frame.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Members
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Members used within cross frame.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Position
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Position of cross frame relative to alignment.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Girder Segment Left
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Connection to girder on left as facing direction of alignment.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Girder Segment Right
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Connection to girder on right as facing direction of alignment.

DocConceptRoot.Name: Diaphragm
DocConceptRoot.Documentation: Diaphragms refer to sections of bridge girders immediately above supporting structures that provide additional lateral and vertical support. Diaphragms are modeled similarly as concrete girder segments, except are distinguished according to a predefined type (e.g. IfcBeamTypeEnum.DIAPHRAGM), and have connections to underlying supports.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Name
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Name of the diaphragm for referencing purposes as would be found on construction plans.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Material
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Material of the girder segment.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Solid Geometry
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Geometry defined as a cross section that may be constant or variable (linearly or parabolic), swept along the alignment at starting and ending positions.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Connection Head
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Relationship connecting head of diaphragm with a girder segment.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Connection Tail
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Relationship connecting tail of diaphragm with a girder segment.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Connection Support
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Relationship connecting diaphragm to substructure, where realizing element refers to bearing if present.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Reinforcing
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: For concrete diaphragms, reinforcing embedded.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Tendons
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: For concrete diaphragms, tendons embedded.

DocConceptRoot.Name: Truss
DocConceptRoot.Documentation: Trusses refer to a framework of linear structural elements in tension and compression for supporting the span of a bridge superstructure. Within a truss, struts refer to compression elements, and ties refer to tension elements.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Name
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Name of the truss for referencing purposes as would be found on construction plans.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Members
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Members within truss, each having connections to gusset plates.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Gusset Plates
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Gusset plates connecting truss memers.

DocTemplateUsage.Name: Connections
DocTemplateUsage.Documentation: Relationships connecting truss to other superstructure elements.
